Dear Ms. Stenzel:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
11/5/2021. The Exit Conference was held with you on 11/9/2021. Due to the violations, a
written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(2) The foster parent/agency agreement shall contain all of the
following provisions:
(e) The role of the lawyer guardian ad litem and the court.
Five of six open foster home records reviewed showed part (e)
of this rule was not contained in the foster parent/agency
agreement.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as determined by
observation of, and interviews with, each member of the
household and each social service worker who has had children
placed in the home during the last licensing period.
One of six open foster home records reviewed did not show that
all household members were interviewed in/during the annual
reevaluation.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2019.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of one borrowed home record reviewed showed (f) and (g)
was not completed by timeframes required by the rule. Each
was completed with the foster parent 20 days after the child’s
placement effective date.
4

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
(e) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
(d):
One of three special evaluations did not show clear and
consistent documentation of the place of all contacts, persons
interviewed and the specific interviewer within the evaluation.
An interview with the foster parents/household members about
the specific allegations was not clearly documented.
(e):
One of three special evaluations reviewed did not show clear
documentation and summarization of how the agency arrived at
findings of fact based on the evaluation.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020, Renewal 20219.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and
their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure
of this information shall be properly safeguarded by the
childcare organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information. Records that are
confidential under this section are available to both of the
following:
5

One of three special evaluations listed the foster children’s full
names in the report; and indicated CPS involvement in the
investigation.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020, Renewal 2019.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One of three initial service plans (ISP) reviewed was completed
four days late.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of a quarterly
medical passport due for February 2021.
 A second record did not show documentation of a
quarterly medical passport due for August 2021.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2019.
6

ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a September or October 2021 meeting.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
Quarterly progress reports (DHHA-614) are to be completed
each quarter.
One of eight child adoption records reviewed, where the child’s
adoption was still pending, showed quarterly adoption progress
reports for 2019 and 2020 were not documented. The agency
only completed an annual child assessment addendum for each
year. The child is placed out of state and there were adoption
family assessment issues for the relative.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020, Renewal 2019.
FOM 722-6H Documentation of contacts
All case contacts must be documented in MISACWIS and
indicated in the service plan.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
The child’s 5/26/2021-8/25/2021 USP did not show
documentation of foster care worker/supervisor meetings. Nor
documentation of an indicated 8/18/2021 and 8/23/2021 foster
home visit.
FOM 722-8 Initial service plan.
Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of the
report.
One of three initial service plans reviewed was approved 30
days late.
7

Repeat Violation- Interim 2020, Renewal 2019.
FOM 722-9 Updated service plan.
Supervisory approval
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
Report Date.
Four of 14 updated service plans reviewed were late:
 One child’s:
 2/24/2021-5/24/2021 USP was completed on 5/24/2021
and approved eight days late on 6/15/2021.
 5/25/2021-8/20/2021 USP was completed on 8/20/2021
and approved six days late on 9/9/2021.
 A second child’s:
 10/1/2020-12/17/2020 USP was completed on
12/17/2020 and approved four days late on 1/4/2021.
 12/18/2020-3/17/2021 USP was completed on 3/17/2021
and approved 12 days late on 4/12/2021.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020, Renewal 2019.
FOM 722-8E
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MISACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change:
Case Closure:
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance of an action summary for the child’s reported
1/22/2021 case closure.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020, Renewal 2019 cited under
FOM 722-9C.
SRM 200 Fingerprints.
Personnel Training:
All personnel, contractors, vendors, and external auditors who
have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete Security
Awareness Training (SAT). Training is available on the Learning
8

Management System (LMS) for MDHHS personnel and
contractors with access to LMS.
SAT is required to be taken six months of working in a position
with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter. CPAs
are responsible for ensuring all personnel with CHRI access
complete SAT timely. SAT certificates must be maintained in all
employee personnel files and/or their LMS transcript to confirm
completion of training.
Five of nine current employees, and one of three employees
who departed the agency, who were indicated to have access to
CHRI did not show compliance:
The respective employee either did not complete the initial or
updated training timely as required by this standard.
Repeat Violation Renewal 2019 cited under Communication
Issuance (CI-16-182a)
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
 The agency is apprised it shall clearly and consistently document when the
applicant’s initial evaluation (3130) was provided the applicant.
Policy-ADM-330 Adoption quarterly progress report.
 The agency is apprised it shall clearly and consistently document that the child
was seen privately and document all courtesy contacts if applicable.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Nothing this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were one incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
This incident related to sexual maltreatment allegations against the foster father
toward the foster daughter. The children in the home were replacement from the
home following the allegations. The special evaluation evidence determined merits
to the allegations; and revocation of the foster home’s license was recommended.
The agency adhered to all departmental timeframes, but received violations related
to R400.12327(5)(d)(e) and Act 116-722.120(3) as indicated in the report.
9

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
That correction action plan related to the agency’s 2020 Interim inspection where it
received the following violations:
 Act 116-722.120(3) related to safeguarding the department’s records on children
and their families.
 R400.12212(2)(d) for Personnel records, related to references.
 R400.12212(3)(a) for Personnel records, related to written performance
evaluations.
 R400.12312(4) for Foster Parent Training, related to foster parent first aid
certification.
 R400.12324(8) for Reevaluation, related to a recommendation to the department.
 R400.12326(1)(c) for Borrowed home, related to endorsement of the certifying
agency’s initial evaluation.
 R400.12326(2) for Borrowed home, related to securing certification
documentation annually from the certifying agency.
 R400.12327(3) for Special evaluation, related to timely completion of the special
evaluation.
 R400.12327(5)(d) for Special evaluation, related to documentation of dates and
places of contacts, and names of persons interviewed and interviewer within the
special evaluation.
 R400.12327(5)(e) for Special evaluation, related to documentation of findings of
facts based on the evaluation.
 R400.1237(7) for Special evaluation, related providing a copy of the foster
parent’s corrective action plan/what ‘s required of the foster parent to service
workers who had children in the foster home.
 R400.12419(1) (c) for Initial service plans, related to placement criteria
assessment.
 R400.12607(4) for Agency recommendation, related to providing a copy of the
adoption evaluation and recommendation to the applicant upon completion.
 Policy- ADM 330 for Quarterly adoption progress reports being completed
quarterly.
 Policy-FOM-722-6B for Family team meetings.
 Policy-FOM-722-8 for Initial service plans, related to supervisory approval.
 Policy-FOM-722-8C for Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan Agreement
and signatures by foster parents.
 Policy-FOM-722-8E for Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
 Policy FOM-722-9 for Updated service plans, related to supervisory approval.
10

 Policy-FOM-722-15 for Case closure documentation related to document to be
provide to birth parents/guardians at case closure.
The agency was not totally successful with completion of that corrective action plan. As
indicated in this report, it received repeat violations for Act 116-722.120(3);
R400.12327(5)(d) & (e); Policy-ADM 330 for Quarterly adoption progress reports;
Policy-FOM-722-8 for Initial service plans; Policy-FOM 722-8E for Foster Care/ Juvenile
Justice Action Summary; and Policy-FOM-722-9 for updated service plans.
It is noteworthy the agency has experienced additional growth causing it to seek
additional space in their office building. Their primary facility address remains their #301
Suite, which houses some administrative staff, and its foster care and licensing staff. In
a prior year the agency had leased suite #215 on the second floor for some
administrative staff. This November, the agency withdrew from that second-floor office
and leased two additional office suites on the first floor consisting of a total of 3000
square feet. Each Suite will have secure key entrance.
Suite# 110 has two staff offices utilized respectively by the chief administrator, and chief
financial officer; a large greeting area, an area for case aides, storage areas for
clothing, donations, and supplies; bathroom, kitchen area with microwave and average
size refrigerator and cabinets. Suite 110 also has three parent/child visitation rooms,
with the availability for a fourth visitation room. Each room has a sink and overhead
cabinets. All offices and rooms are modernly furnished with an adequate number of
desks, chairs, supplies and equipment to meet staff and parent/child visitation needs.
Suite #120 houses the agency’s domestic and state ward adoption staff along with the
administrative assistant. This suite consists of eight and a half offices, two large
conference rooms, a full bathroom with shower and tub, a large greeting area, and
administrative assistant’s office unit, which has a side office, equipment area and
nearby bathroom. This suite is also modernly furnished with an adequate number of
desks, chairs, cabinets, supplies and secure storage space for files, to meet the staff
and agency’s operational needs.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts indicated this inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
